fields.featuredescription: optimization for heavily updated tables
Delays writes to WAL for committed transactions
automatic smoothening of checkpoints to reduce sudden I/O spikes
allows the autovacuum daemon to operate on multiple tables concurrently

fields.featurename: Scrollable and updatable cursor support for pl/pgsql

fields.featurename: ROWS and COST specification for functions
fields.featuredescription: CPU costs and the number of expected rows can now be specified for procedural functions to give better hints to the planner
allows simple access to the SQL error state and the associated error text if an exception happened
UTF8 support for the contributed tsearch2 full text search engine
addon to get the on-disk size of various database objects, built in since 8.1
Server configuration parameters can now be set on a per-function basis

optimizes sort operations for ORDER BY x LIMIT ionsy like operat
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/sql-select.html
enabled sequential scans to piggyback on concurrently running scans

fields.featurename: Loadable plugin infrastructure for monitoring the planner
fields.featuredescription: allows plugins to augment or even replace the planner (like for providing an index advisor)
allows multiple tablespaces to be defined for temporary operations
allows the creation of arrays of arbitrary complex compound types

allows the backend to be compiled with Microsoft Visual Studio

array elements can contain NULL
online index creation without locking the table

enables the query planner to reorder out joins

https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/sql-prepare-transaction.html
replaces user and group concept by a more generalizes role based concept
enabled the planner to combine multiple indexes using an in-memory bitmap
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/routine-vacuuming.html#AUTOVACUUM
reduces deadlock scenarios with foreign keys
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/ddl-partitioning.html
allows restrictions on the number of connections a given user or database will be allowed to make or accept
allows the creation of temporary VIEWs
allows for disabling and enabling a specific or all triggers on a given table
Native Port to the Microsoft Windows Platform

https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/sql-createtablespace.html

Full Support for IPv6
allows the planner to inline most SQL functions into the whole query

Triggers that fire on a per statement level instead of a per row level

compile time validation of pl/pgsql code
allows the use of named parameters in pl/pgsql
full exception handling support in pl/pgsql
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/pageinspect.html
set of functions to generate UUIDs

advisory lock support - moved into the backend
automatic vacuum daemon - moved into the backend
full support for using UTF8 on microsoft windows

provides support for levenshtein/soundex/metaphone
full integration with the native authentication framework in Microsoft Windows
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/warm-standby.html
allows index usage with IS NULL expressions
allows hashing to be used across compatible but not identical datatypes
allows user defined datatypes to specify a type modifier
database owners can now create trusted languages
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/routine-vacuuming.html#AUTOVACUUM
obsoleted client protocol interface
Advanced locking for concurrent modification of GiST indexes
full support for using UTF8 and other multibyte encodings
https://babel.postgresql.org/
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/sql-altertable.html
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/ssl-tcp.html

compatibility wrapper for migrating from contrib/tsearch2 to the integrated full text search in 8.3
Trigger support for TRUNCATE
allows the use of CASE as a conditional expression in addition to IF-THEN
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/gin-implementation.html#GIN-PARTIAL-MATCH
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/queries-with.html
Support for different collation order and character categories on a per database level
case insensitive text datatype
allows hashing to be used in query plans involving DISTINCT/UNION/EXCEPT/INTERSECT
SQL standard RETURNS TABLE clause for CREATE FUNCTION
Allows a variable number of function parameters
allows to generate user defined exceptions through RAISE

`unnest` allows for arrays to be "unnested" and expanded into a set of rows.

Conversely, `array_agg` can take the output of a set of rows and aggregate them into an array.

For more information:

- [Array Functions](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/functions-array.html)
- [Aggregation Functions](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/functions-aggregate.html)
replaces the shared memory fixed size free space map with an on-disk implemenation
runtime statistics for user-defined functions
allows for returning the result of a dynamically generated query
certificate validation in libpq
Automatic logging of the plans of slow-running queries

SQL standard shorthand version for `SELECT * FROM`

For more information, please see the documentation on [`SELECT`](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/sql-select.html)
allows authentication of clients by the use of an SSL certificate
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/tutorial-window.html
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/8.4/static/pgstatstatements.html
allows specification of granular column-level permissions in addition to table level grants
allows pg_restore to restore data from custom format dumps in parallel
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/8.4/static/btree-gin.html
Allows [psql](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/app-psql.html) to work with older versions of PostgreSQL.
allows specification of unicode string literals and identifiers using code points
This reduces the overhead of vacuuming as the visibility map tracks only the pages that need to be vacuumed.
support for compiling PostgreSQL using the Sun Studio compiler on Linux
adds support for SQL standard column level trigger support, by allowing triggers to only fire if specific columns are mentioned in the UPDATEs SET list
allows unique constraint checking to be deferred until the end of the transaction

fields.featurename: XML, JSON and YAML output for EXPLAIN
fields.featuredescription: Adds XML, JSON and YAML output to EXPLAIN to help with automatic processing of plans
allows the specification of default permissions for objects
allows the execution of anonymous code blocks in pl/pgsql
simplifies permission management by allowing mass changes of GRANTS

fields.featurename: Prefix support for text search synonym dictionary

fields.featuredescription: provides for per user/database server configuration settings
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/unaccent.html
Add the ability to retrieve asynchronous notifications using dblink

fields.featurename: Spinlock support for the SuperH hardware platform
fields.featuredescription: s_lock support for the SuperH CPU
adds support for a boolean expression to be checked if a trigger should be fired or not
generalizes the concept of uniqueness to support any indexable commutative operator, not just equality
allows controlling the order of values fed into an aggregate function
adds the ability to show buffer-usage statistics for a query
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/passwordcheck.html
Access controls on large objects

fields.featurename: Search+bind mode operation for LDAP authentication
fields.featuredescription: Allows searching for the user in the directory first, and then binds with the DN found for this user
pl/pgsql is now installed by default in all newly created database
allows the execution of anonymous code blocks in pl/perl
support for Python 3 in pl/python
allow read only connections during recovery
Adds support for syntax: CREATE TABLE name OF type
[`NOTIFY`](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/sql-notify.html) can send payload data, which can be received by [`LISTEN`](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/sql-listen.html)
Allows for setting seq_page_cost and random_page_cost on a per tablespace level
Integrated replication support based on streaming WAL data
adds support for authentictaing against a RADIUS server
support for compiling PostgreSQL as a 64bit binary on Microsoft Windows

pg_upgrade (formerly called pg_migrator) allows data stored in PostgreSQL data files to be migrated to a later PostgreSQL major version without the data dump/reload typically required for major version upgrades
sepgsql is a loadable module which supports label-based mandatory access control (MAC) based on SELinux security policy.
auth_delay causes the server to pause briefly before reporting authentication failure, to make brute-force attacks on database passwords more difficult.
The file_fdw module provides the foreign-data wrapper file_fdw, which can be used to access data files in the server file system.
allows nearest-neighbor support to contrib/pg_trgm and contrib/btree_gist

Such tables provide better update performance than regular tables, but are not crash-safe: their contents are automatically cleared in case of a server crash. Their contents do not propagate to replication slaves, either.

fields.featurename: Hashing support for FULL OUTER JOIN, LEFT OUTER JOIN and RIGHT OUTER JOIN
fields.featuredescription: allows FULL OUTER JOIN to be implemented as a hash join, and allow either side of a LEFT OUTER JOIN or RIGHT OUTER JOIN to be hashed
allows Unix-based GSSAPI clients to do SSPI authentication with Windows servers.
wal_buffers is now auto-tuned by default based on the size of shared_buffers

This allows the primary to wait for a standby to write the transaction information to disk before acknowledging the commit. One standby at a time can take the role of the synchronous standby, as controlled by the synchronous_standby_names setting. Synchronous replication can be enabled or disabled on a per-transaction basis using the synchronous_commit setting.
pg_basebackup is a tool to take a base backup of a PostgreSQL cluster
Create a named point for performing restore using pg_create_restore_point
Allows INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE in WITH clauses which can be used in conjunction with a RETURNING clause to to pass data up to the containing query.

This implements true serializable snapshot isolation. Previously, asking for serializable isolation guaranteed only that a single MVCC snapshot would be used for the entire transaction, which allowed certain documented anomalies.
Previously collation could only be set at database creation. Collation can now be set per column, domain, index, or expression, via the SQL-standard COLLATE clause.
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/external-extensions.html
This allows data stored outside the database to be used like native PostgreSQL-stored data.

fields.featurename: ALTER TABLE ... ADD UNIQUE/PRIMARY KEY USING INDEX
fields.featuredescription: This allows a primary key or unique constraint to be defined using an existing unique index, including a concurrently created unique index.

fields.featurename: Foreign keys marked as NOT VALID
fields.featuredescription: This introduces a new option to the creation of foreign keys called NOT VALID, which can later be modified to VALIDATED and validation checks performed. Together these allow you to add a foreign key with minimal impact on read and write operations.
This adds support for INSTEAD OF triggers on views which can be used to implement fully updatable views.
This is more efficient and readable than previous methods of iterating through the elements of an array value.

Also known as "covering indexes", allows data in indexes to satisfy queries where all columns in a given query are covered by the index.  This removes the requirement of having to visit the table pages, which was required previously to get visibility information, but now the visibility map is used instead.

Improve concurrent read-only workloads on multi-core servers.  Previously this had limited scalability offering performance benefits only up to a few cores, but now performance gains are seen utilising all cores in 32 and 64 core servers.
Standbys can now stream to other standbys, reducing replication load on the primary server.
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.2/static/datatype-json.html
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.2/static/rangetypes.html
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/spgist.html
A serial data type that uses smallint (2 byte integer) as its base type, giving it a reduced numeric range, but a smaller data footprint.
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.2/static/tcn.html
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/app-pgreceivewal.html
pg_stat_statements now aggregates similar queries so that such data is no longer confined to just prepared queries.

Originally the background writer held responsibility for writing checkpoints, but it has now been moved into its own separate process and the background writer is now only responsible for writing dirty pages to disk.  This provides advantages related to performance and power-reduction.
Many objects now support IF EXISTS clauses on ALTER statements, such as tables, foreign tables, indexes, sequences etc.

fields.featurename: CREATE TABLE ... (LIKE) with foreign tables, views and composite types

fields.featuredescription: This prevents security_barrier views from being moved into other scopes, preventing possible leakage of view-prohibited data.
SQL-standard LATERAL option for FROM-clause subqueries and function calls.
Large objects are now 64-bit and can now be up to 4TB where before it was up to 2GB.
Support for creating triggers for DDL events.
Simple views can now have UPDATE/INSERT/DELETE performed against them.
pg_dump now has a --jobs option to dump tables in parallel.
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/rules-materializedviews.html
The foreign data wrapper infrastructure now supports INSERT/DELETE/UPDATE operations which individual FDWs can now add support for.
Foreign data wrappers allow access to external data for querying.
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/postgres-fdw.html
Previously sizing shared memory often required adjusting kernel parameters to accommodate the change.  This is no longer necessary.
Background worker processes can now be added that can attach to PostgreSQL's shared memory.

fields.featurename: SELECT FOR NO KEY UPDATE/SELECT FOR KEY SHARE lock modes
fields.featuredescription: These prevent non-key-field row updates from locking foreign key rows.
Clusters can now be created with checksums on pages to detect and report page corruption.
Cascading replication previously required that an xlog archive be available in order for a standbys of the new primary to correctly switch to the new timeline.  This change removes this dependency.
Displays a human-readable rendering of the write-ahead log of a PostgreSQL database cluster.
Regular expressions can now be indexed using GIN in contrib/pg_trgm.
GiST and SP-GiST indexes can be created for table columns of range types.
COPY and psql's \copy now support piping from and to STDIN and STDOUT respectively.

fields.featurename: Improved set of JSON functions and operators
fields.featuredescription: New operators and functions to extract values from JSON data strings, JSON data strings can now to be converted into records and new functions to convert values, records, and hstore data to JSON.
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.4/static/datatype-json.html
Materialized views which can be refreshed with REFRESH MATERIALIZED VIEW CONCURRENTLY name;
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.4/static/sql-altersystem.html
native Kerberos 5 wire authentication (replaced with GSSAPI)
Allows background workers to be started and stopped dynamically by any user process.
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.4/static/warm-standby.html#STREAMING-REPLICATION-SLOTS

fields.featurename: GIN Index performance and size improvements
fields.featuredescription: GIN Indexes now take up significantly less space and perform a lot faster than pre-9.4 releases.
A new setting called recovery_min_apply_delay will allow a standby to lag behind the primary by a specified amount of time.

fields.featurename: Reduced lock levels for ALTER TABLE commands
fields.featuredescription:
The following commands now have reduced lock levels for reduced lock contention:

VALIDATE CONSTRAINT

CLUSTER ON
SET WITHOUT CLUSTER

ALTER COLUMN SET STATISTICS
ALTER COLUMN SET ()
ALTER COLUMN RESET ()
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/sql-expressions.html#SYNTAX-AGGREGATES
pg_basebackup now supports throttling of backups with -r <rate> or --max-rate <rate>, allowing control of the data transfer rate of the base backup.
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.4/static/pgprewarm.html
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/queries-table-expressions.html#QUERIES-TABLEFUNCTIONS
Aggregate functions can now be filtered with the FILTER clause.  For example: count(col_a) FILTER (WHERE col_b > 5)

Auto-updatable views can now specify whether an INSERT or UPDATE would change the state of the row so that it would no longer be visible in the view.  Using WITH CHECK OPTION will prevent any such changes from occuring.
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.5/static/sql-importforeignschema.html
Allows tables to switch between logged and unlogged states.
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/sql-createpolicy.html
Skips over rows that are currently locked without waiting.
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/brin-intro.html
The vacuumdb tool now supports an option to define the number of jobs in which to run VACUUM.
Foreign tables can now inherit from other foreign tables or other regular tables.  The reverse also applies.
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.5/static/app-pgrewind.html
GiST indexes now support index-only scans.
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.5/static/sql-createtransform.html

Support for upsert functionality which allows either no action to be taken when a conflict is encountered, or convert the INSERT to an UPDATE.

For more information, please see the [INSERT](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/sql-insert.html) documentation.
New operators and functions which allow deleting, modifying or inserting values into JSONB values, including at specific path locations.
Specifies that a sample of the table is to be used, which is useful for use-cases such as approximate averages.

fields.featurename: GROUPING SETS, CUBE and ROLLUP support
fields.featuredescription: https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/queries-table-expressions.html#QUERIES-GROUPING-SETS

The abbreviated keys optimization can be expected to greatly enhance the performance of sorts in PostgreSQL, including those used for CREATE INDEX. Reportedly, in some cases, CREATE INDEX on text columns can be as much as an entire order of magnitude faster (3x is a more typical improvement). Numeric sorts also support the optimization.

Replaces `checkpoint_segments` parameter.

For more information, please see the [WAL configuration](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/wal-configuration.html) documentation.
Ability to execute multiple query nodes in parallel processes.
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/parallel-plans.html#PARALLEL-SCANS
Ability to execute some kinds of JOINs, as well as aggregates, using multiple parallel processes.
Ability to push down JOIN, Sorts, UPDATEs and DELETEs to the remote database in postgres_fdw driver, and theoretically in other drivers.  Also some generic operator/function pushdown.
Ability to require synch messages from multiple prioritized standbys when committing a synchronous transaction.
Ability to require that synchronous replicas be caught up with the master in applying changes before commit.  Supports "consistent clustering".
Frozen page data in visibility map to prevent re-vacuuming already-frozen pages during wraparound.
KNN indexing support for the CUBE module.  Supports n-dimensional nearest neighbor searches.
Fulltext search for phrases and word proximity.
New system view to display information about the PostgreSQL build, storage, and build configuration options.
Consistent, simple API for WAL-logging of database objects, supporting new index access methods and other storage objects.
Ability to automatically pull in required additional extensions for an extension dependency tree.
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/10/static/logical-replication.html
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/10/static/ddl-partitioning.html#ddl-partitioning-declarative

As described in RFC 7677, SCRAM-SHA-256 authentication provides challenge-response scheme, that prevents password sniffing on untrusted connections. It is more secure than the md5 method, but might not be supported by older clients.

SCRAM-SHA-256 authentication can be enabled in the host-based authentication configuration file.

Using the synchronous_standby_names configuration parameter, synchronous replication can be setup to allow for any number of standbys to confirm writes have been committed, irrespective of their ordering. This is also known as "quorum commit."
B-tree index pages can be searched by separate parallel workers.
A single index scan can dispatch parallel workers to process different areas of the heap.
Merge joins can be performed in parallel.
Hash indexes have write-ahead log support, which makes them both crash safe and replicable.
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/10/static/datatype-net-types.html#datatype-macaddr8

fields.featurename: Parallelized CREATE INDEX for B-tree indexes
Support for PRIMARY KEY, FOREIGN KEY, indexes, and triggers on partitioned tables
CREATE PROCEDURE syntax for SQL stored procedures
fields.featuredescription: https://www.postgresql.org/docs/11/static/sql-createprocedure.html
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/parallel-plans.html#PARALLEL-JOINS

fields.featurename: Just-in-Time (JIT) compilation for expression evaluation and tuple deforming
fields.featuredescription: https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/jit.html
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/sasl-authentication.html#SASL-SCRAM-SHA-256
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/11/static/sql-call.html
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/collation.html#id-1.6.10.4.5.7.5
A default partition stores data that does not match the partition key for any other partition, i.e. it is a "catch all" partition.
When a partition key is updated on a row, the row is moved to the appropriate partition.

Allows additional columns to be included in as "non-key" columns in an index, and if requirements are met, can return data from these columns in an index-only scan.

Fore more information, please see the documentation on [Index-Only Scans & Covering Indexes](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/indexes-index-only-scans.html).

Allows additional columns to be included in as "non-key" columns in a GiST index, and if requirements are met, can return data from these columns in an index-only scan.

Fore more information, please see the documentation on [Index-Only Scans & Covering Indexes](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/indexes-index-only-scans.html).
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/functions-json.html#FUNCTIONS-SQLJSON-PATH
Add support for K-nearest neighbor (K-NN) searches on SP-GiST indexes when the distance operator `<->` is defined.

CREATE STATISTICS provides the ability to collect statistics over multiple columns, which can be used by the optimizer to generate better query plans.

https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/sql-createstatistics.html
CREATE STATISTICS  can collection statistics on the most common value, which can improve optimizations for columns that contain nonuniform distributions.

fields.featurename: Foreign Key references for partitioned tables
fields.featuredescription: A foreign key can reference a partitioned table.
Performance improvements for queries on tables with thousands of partitions when only a limited subset of partitions need to be accessed.

A WITH query that is neither recursive nor has any side-effects (e.g. an INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE) can be executed inline, which can lead to performance improvements. This behavior can be forced on a query by using the "NOT MATERIALIZED" clause, e.g.

```
WITH cte AS NOT MATERIALIZED (
    SELECT * FROM a
)
SELECT * FROM cte
JOIN b ON b.id = cte.id;
```

For more information, please visit [https://www.postgresql.org/docs/12/queries-with.html](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/12/queries-with.html)
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/ddl-generated-columns.html
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/12/collation.html#COLLATION-NONDETERMINISTIC

Support for client and server-side connection encryption when using GSSAPI for authentication.

https://www.postgresql.org/docs/12/gssapi-auth.html

LDAP servers with DNS SRV can be discovered if PostgreSQL is built with OpenLDAP

https://www.postgresql.org/docs/12/auth-ldap.html

fields.featurename: Multifactor authentication via valid client SSL/TLS certificate
fields.featuredescription:
If an authentication entry in the pg_hba.conf specifies the `clientcert=verify-full`, then the client must present a valid SSL certificate that matches the login name, or the client name based on a map.

[https://www.postgresql.org/docs/12/ssl-tcp.html#SSL-CLIENT-CERTIFICATES](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/12/ssl-tcp.html#SSL-CLIENT-CERTIFICATES)
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/sql-reindex.html#SQL-REINDEX-CONCURRENTLY

fields.featurename: Enable/Disable page checksums in an offline cluster
fields.featuredescription:
Page checksums can be enabled or disabled in an offline PostgreSQL cluster via the pg_checksums command:

https://www.postgresql.org/docs/12/app-pgchecksums.html

Fractional input for "integer" server variables is now accepted e.g.

SET work_mem = '24.2MB'
Specify which rows are loaded from a data source via a WHERE clause when using COPY FROM
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/12/sql-create-access-method.html

Queries on partitioned tables can eliminate partitions during query execution time, instead of only at query planning time. This allows PostgreSQL to use information that becomes available during query execution to further prune the number of partitions it needs to use, leading to improved query performance.
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/13/btree-implementation.html#BTREE-DEDUPLICATION
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/13/runtime-config-query.html#GUC-ENABLE-INCREMENTAL-SORT

Extend statistics can help the query planner provided better plans for queries that have "OR".clauses as well as "IN/ANY" lookups over lists. For more information, please see https://www.postgresql.org/docs/13/planner-stats.html#PLANNER-STATS-EXTENDED

The query planner can now consider using hash aggregation if it expects the aggregate to exceed working memory.

This can be controlled by two configuration parameters:

- [enable_hashagg](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/13/runtime-config-query.html#GUC-ENABLE-HASHAGG)
- [hash_mem_multiplier](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/13/runtime-config-resource.html#GUC-HASH-MEM-MULTIPLIER)
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/queries-with.html

fields.featurename: Client can require SCRAM channel binding
fields.featuredescription: https://www.postgresql.org/docs/13/libpq-connect.html#LIBPQ-CONNECT-CHANNEL-BINDING

The [postgres_fdw](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/13/postgres-fdw.html) can now use the built-in [certificate authentication](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/auth-cert.html) mechanism.

For more information, please visit the [postgres_fdw documentation](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/13/postgres-fdw.html#id-1.11.7.42.10)

The VACUUM process can be parallelized for indexes. The number of VACUUM jobs for an index can be specified.

For more information, please see the [VACUUM documentation](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/sql-vacuum.html)
This new behavior reduces the work necessary when the table needs to be frozen and allows pages to be set as all-visible. All-visible pages allow index-only scans to access fewer heap rows.

fields.featurename: Configure max WAL retention for replication slots
fields.featuredescription: https://www.postgresql.org/docs/13/runtime-config-replication.html#GUC-MAX-SLOT-WAL-KEEP-SIZE
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/13/app-pgverifybackup.html
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/13/sql-select.html#SQL-LIMIT
Fully supports logical replication of partitioned tables.

The SQL/JSON path `datetime()` function in JSON path expressions converts valid date and time formats (e.g. ISO 8601) to their corresponding PostgreSQL type.

For more information, see the [JSON path documentation](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/13/functions-json.html#FUNCTIONS-SQLJSON-OP-TABLE)

Extensions that are marked as "trusted" by a superuser can subsequently be installed via `CREATE EXTENSION` by unprivileged users. Some functions are marked as "trusted" by default.

For more information, please see the [`CREATE EXTENSION`](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/sql-createextension.html) documentation.

[EXPLAIN](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/13/sql-explain.html) can now track WAL usage information along with [auto_explain](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/13/auto-explain.html), [autovacuum](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/13/routine-vacuuming.html#AUTOVACUUM), and [pg_stat_statements](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/13/pgstatstatements.html).

For more information, please see the documentation on [EXPLAIN](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/13/sql-explain.html).
